content.text: Measure and record the height \(h\), width \(w\) and depth \(d\) of your transparent block
Label the corners of your outline \(\mathbf{A}, \mathbf{B}, \mathbf{C}\) and \(\mathbf{D}\), as shown in Fig. 1.2
On your diagram, draw a line \(\mathbf{AC}\)
Measure and record the angle \(\alpha\) between lines \(\mathbf{AD}\) and \(\mathbf{AC}\)
Place the block in the space below with the **smallest** face in contact with the Carefully draw round the outline, as shown in Fig. 1.2. Remove the block from the p
Hold the protractor next to face ABCD of the block as shown in Fig. 1.3. Gently push the top of the block (as indicated in Fig. 1.3) until the block tips over
Record the angle \(\theta\), between side \(\mathbf{BC}\) of the block and the vertical line on the protractor, when the block just starts to tip over
Repeat steps (i) and (ii) a suitable number of times for this experiment. Record the readings in the space below

Calculate the average \(\theta_{\mathrm{av}}\) of all your values for \(\theta\). Show your working. Give your value of \(\theta_{\mathrm{av}}\) to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment
Place the block on the paper towel at the edge of the bench, as shown in Fig. 1
A student suggests that \(\theta_{\mathrm{av}}\) should be equal to \(\alpha\)
State whether your results support this suggestion. Justify your statement by reference to your results
statement
justification
The aim of this experiment is to investigate the stability of a block
Carry out the following instructions referring to Figs. 1.1, 1.2 and 1.3
Fig. 1.2
Record the value of room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) shown on the thermometer
You are provided with a supply of hot water. Pour \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker. Place the thermometer into the beaker of hot water, as shown in Fig. 2.1
When the thermometer reading stops rising, measure the temperature \(\theta\) of the water in the beaker and immediately start the stopclock. Record \(\theta\) in Table 2.1 at time \(t = 0s\)
Record in the table the time \(t\) and the temperature \(\theta\) of the water every 30s until you have a total of seven readings.

Measure and record in the table the distance \(d\) from the bottom end of your thermometer to the position of the first temperature reading in the table. Fig. 2.2 shows a measurement of \(d\) being made for a temperature of \(81^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). You must use your own temperature reading and thermometer
Measure \(d\) for all the other temperature readings. Record your values in the table
Complete the column headings in the table
Remove the thermometer from the beaker and the clamp
Explain how the graph line shows that \(\theta\) is not directly proportional to \(d\)
Suggest why, when \(\theta = 0^\circ \mathrm{C}\), the value of \(d\) is not zero
Describe briefly the method you would use to determine, as accurately as possible, the distance between the \(1^\circ \mathrm{C}\) marks on the thermometer
A student carried out this experiment and plotted a graph of \(\theta\) against \(d.\) A sketch
graph obtained is shown in Fig. 2.3
In this experiment, you will investigate the scale of a thermometer
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Figs. 2.1 and 2.2
Switch on. Measure, and record in Table 3.1, the current \(I\) in the circuit and the potential difference \(V\) across a length \(x = 10.0 \text{cm}\) of the wire \(\mathbf{AB}\). Switch off
Calculate the resistance \(R\) of \(10.0 \text{cm}\) of the wire \(\mathbf{AB}\), using the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\). Record this value of \(R\) in the table
Complete the column headings in the table
Repeat steps (i) and (ii) with values of \(x\) equal to \(30.0 \text{cm}\), \(50.0 \text{cm}\), \(70.0 \text{cm}\) and \(90.0 \text{cm}\)
Plot a graph of \(V / V\) (y-axis) against \(R / \Omega\) (x-axis)
Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
In this experiment, you will investigate the resistance of a wire
The circuit shown in Fig. 3.1 has been set up for you
Draw a line 10.0cm long near the middle of the ray-trace sheet. Label the line MR
a normal to this line that passes through its centre. Label the normal NL. Label the line at which NL crosses MR with the letter B
Draw a line 8.0cm long from \(\mathbf{B}\) at an angle of incidence \(i = 30^{\circ}\) to the normal below MR and to the left of the normal. Label the end of this line \(\mathbf{A}\)
Place a pin \(\mathsf{P}_1\) on line \(\mathbf{AB}\) at a distance 7.0cm from \(\mathbf{B}\)
Place a pin \(\mathsf{P}_2\) on line \(\mathbf{AB}\) at a distance 1.0cm from \(\mathbf{B}\)
Place the reflecting face of the mirror vertically on the line MR

View the images of pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 4.1. Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) some distance apart so that pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\), and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_2\) and \(\mathsf{P}_1\), all appear exactly one behind the other. Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\)
Remove the pins and the mirror and draw the line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\). Continue the line until it crosses MR and extends at least 8.0cm beyond MR
Place pin \(\mathsf{P}_2\) 1.0cm to the right of its position in part (d)
(j) Repeat the steps in parts (e) to (g)
(k) Label with a \(\mathbf{Y}\) the point where the two lines beyond MR cross
Draw a line from the point labelled \(\mathbf{Y}\) to MR that meets MR at a right angle. Measure and record the length \(b\) of this line
(m) A student suggests that the length \(a\) should be equal to the length \(b\)
State whether your results support this suggestion. Justify your statement by reference to your results
statement
justification
Replace pin \(\mathsf{P}_1\) on line \(\mathbf{AB}\) in the same position as in (c), at a distance 7.0cm from \(\mathbf{B}\)
In this experiment, you will investigate the position of the image in a plane mirror
Carry out the following instructions referring to Fig. 4.1
